trans-unit.source: Service Bus REST tutorial | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Service Bus REST tutorial | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Build a simple Service Bus host application that exposes a REST-based interface.
trans-unit.target: Build a simple Service Bus host application that exposes a REST-based interface.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial describes how to build a simple Service Bus host application that exposes a REST-based interface.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial describes how to build a simple Service Bus host application that exposes a REST-based interface.

trans-unit.source: REST enables a web client, such as a web browser, to access the Service Bus API through HTTP requests.
trans-unit.target: REST enables a web client, such as a web browser, to access the Service Bus API through HTTP requests.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses the Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) REST programming model to construct a REST service on Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses the Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) REST programming model to construct a REST service on Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>WCF REST Programming Model</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Designing and Implementing Services</linkText><title></title> in the WCF documentation.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>WCF REST Programming Model</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Designing and Implementing Services</linkText><title></title> in the WCF documentation.

trans-unit.source: The first step is to create a service namespace, and to obtain a Shared Access Signature (SAS) key.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to create a service namespace, and to obtain a Shared Access Signature (SAS) key.

trans-unit.source: A service namespace provides an application boundary for each application exposed through Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: A service namespace provides an application boundary for each application exposed through Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: A SAS key is automatically generated by the system when a service namespace is created.
trans-unit.target: A SAS key is automatically generated by the system when a service namespace is created.

trans-unit.source: The combination of service namespace and SAS key provides the credentials for Service Bus to authenticate access to an application.
trans-unit.target: The combination of service namespace and SAS key provides the credentials for Service Bus to authenticate access to an application.

trans-unit.source: To create a namespace in the Azure portal, follow the steps in <linkText>How To: Create or Modify a Service Bus Service Namespace</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To create a namespace in the Azure portal, follow the steps in <linkText>How To: Create or Modify a Service Bus Service Namespace</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the main window of the Azure portal, click the name of the service namespace you created in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: In the main window of the Azure portal, click the name of the service namespace you created in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: Click Configure to view the shared access policies for the namespace.
trans-unit.target: Click Configure to view the shared access policies for the namespace.

trans-unit.source: Make a note of the primary key for the RootManageSharedAccessKey policy, or copy it to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Make a note of the primary key for the RootManageSharedAccessKey policy, or copy it to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: You will use this value later in the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will use this value later in the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: As with other Service Bus services, when you create a REST-style service, you must define the contract.
trans-unit.target: As with other Service Bus services, when you create a REST-style service, you must define the contract.

trans-unit.source: The contract specifies what operations the host supports.
trans-unit.target: The contract specifies what operations the host supports.

trans-unit.source: A service operation can be thought of as a web service method.
trans-unit.target: A service operation can be thought of as a web service method.

trans-unit.source: Contracts are created by defining a C++, C#, or Visual Basic interface.
trans-unit.target: Contracts are created by defining a C++, C#, or Visual Basic interface.

trans-unit.source: Each method in the interface corresponds to a specific service operation.
trans-unit.target: Each method in the interface corresponds to a specific service operation.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>ServiceContractAttribute</linkText><title></title> attribute must be applied to each interface, and the <linkText>OperationContractAttribute</linkText><title></title> attribute must be applied to each operation.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>ServiceContractAttribute</linkText><title></title> attribute must be applied to each interface, and the <linkText>OperationContractAttribute</linkText><title></title> attribute must be applied to each operation.

trans-unit.source: If a method in an interface that has the <linkText>ServiceContractAttribute</linkText><title></title> does not have the <linkText>OperationContractAttribute</linkText><title></title>, that method is not exposed.
trans-unit.target: If a method in an interface that has the <linkText>ServiceContractAttribute</linkText><title></title> does not have the <linkText>OperationContractAttribute</linkText><title></title>, that method is not exposed.

trans-unit.source: The code used for these tasks is shown in the example following the procedure.
trans-unit.target: The code used for these tasks is shown in the example following the procedure.

trans-unit.source: The primary difference between a basic Service Bus contract and a REST-style contract is the addition of a property to the <linkText>OperationContractAttribute</linkText><title></title>: <linkText>WebGetAttribute</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The primary difference between a basic Service Bus contract and a REST-style contract is the addition of a property to the <linkText>OperationContractAttribute</linkText><title></title>: <linkText>WebGetAttribute</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This property enables you to map a method in your interface to a method on the other side of the interface.
trans-unit.target: This property enables you to map a method in your interface to a method on the other side of the interface.

trans-unit.source: In this case, we will use <linkText>WebGetAttribute</linkText><title></title> to link a method to HTTP GET.
trans-unit.target: In this case, we will use <linkText>WebGetAttribute</linkText><title></title> to link a method to HTTP GET.

trans-unit.source: This allows Service Bus to accurately retrieve and interpret commands sent to the interface.
trans-unit.target: This allows Service Bus to accurately retrieve and interpret commands sent to the interface.

trans-unit.source: Open Visual Studio as an administrator: right-click the program in the Start menu, and then click Run as administrator.
trans-unit.target: Open Visual Studio as an administrator: right-click the program in the Start menu, and then click Run as administrator.

trans-unit.source: Create a new console application project.
trans-unit.target: Create a new console application project.

trans-unit.source: Click the File menu and select New, then select Project.
trans-unit.target: Click the File menu and select New, then select Project.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, click Visual C# (if Visual C# does not appear, look under Other Languages), select the Console Application template, and name it ImageListener.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, click Visual C# (if Visual C# does not appear, look under Other Languages), select the Console Application template, and name it ImageListener.

trans-unit.source: Use the default Location.
trans-unit.target: Use the default Location.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to create the project.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to create the project.

trans-unit.source: For a C# project, Visual Studio creates a Program.cs file.
trans-unit.target: For a C# project, Visual Studio creates a Program.cs file.

trans-unit.source: This class contains an empty Main() method, required for a console application project to build correctly.
trans-unit.target: This class contains an empty Main() method, required for a console application project to build correctly.

trans-unit.source: Add a reference to System.ServiceModel.dll to the project:
trans-unit.target: Add a reference to System.ServiceModel.dll to the project:

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the References folder under the project folder and then click Add Reference.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the References folder under the project folder and then click Add Reference.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: Click the .NET tab in the Add Reference dialog box and scroll down until you see System.ServiceModel.
trans-unit.target: Click the .NET tab in the Add Reference dialog box and scroll down until you see System.ServiceModel.

trans-unit.source: Select it, then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select it, then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Repeat the previous step to add a reference to the System.ServiceModel.Web.dll assembly.
trans-unit.target: Repeat the previous step to add a reference to the System.ServiceModel.Web.dll assembly.

trans-unit.source: Add using statements for the System.ServiceModel, System.ServiceModel.Channels, System.ServiceModel.Web, and System.IO namespaces.
trans-unit.target: Add using statements for the System.ServiceModel, System.ServiceModel.Channels, System.ServiceModel.Web, and System.IO namespaces.

trans-unit.source: Rename the namespace for the program from the Visual Studio default to Microsoft.ServiceBus.Samples.
trans-unit.target: Rename the namespace for the program from the Visual Studio default to Microsoft.ServiceBus.Samples.

trans-unit.source: Directly after the namespace declaration, define a new interface named IImageContract and apply the ServiceContractAttribute attribute to the interface with a value of http://samples.microsoft.com/ServiceModel/Relay/.
trans-unit.target: Directly after the namespace declaration, define a new interface named IImageContract and apply the ServiceContractAttribute attribute to the interface with a value of http://samples.microsoft.com/ServiceModel/Relay/.

trans-unit.source: The namespace value differs from the namespace that you use throughout the scope of your code.
trans-unit.target: The namespace value differs from the namespace that you use throughout the scope of your code.

trans-unit.source: The namespace value is used as a unique identifier for this contract, and should have version information.
trans-unit.target: The namespace value is used as a unique identifier for this contract, and should have version information.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Service Versioning</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Service Versioning</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Specifying the namespace explicitly prevents the default namespace value from being added to the contract name.
trans-unit.target: Specifying the namespace explicitly prevents the default namespace value from being added to the contract name.

trans-unit.source: Within the IImageContract interface, declare a method for the single operation the IImageContract contract exposes in the interface and apply the OperationContractAttribute attribute to the method that you want to expose as part of the public Service Bus contract.
trans-unit.target: Within the IImageContract interface, declare a method for the single operation the IImageContract contract exposes in the interface and apply the OperationContractAttribute attribute to the method that you want to expose as part of the public Service Bus contract.

trans-unit.source: Next to the OperationContract attribute, apply the WebGet attribute.
trans-unit.target: Next to the OperationContract attribute, apply the WebGet attribute.

trans-unit.source: Directly after the IImageContract definition, declare a channel that inherits from both the IImageContract and IClientChannel interfaces.
trans-unit.target: Directly after the IImageContract definition, declare a channel that inherits from both the IImageContract and IClientChannel interfaces.

trans-unit.source: From the Build menu, click Build Solution to confirm the accuracy of your work so far.
trans-unit.target: From the Build menu, click Build Solution to confirm the accuracy of your work so far.

trans-unit.source: The following code example shows a basic interface that defines a Service Bus contract.
trans-unit.target: The following code example shows a basic interface that defines a Service Bus contract.

trans-unit.source: Creating a REST-style Service Bus service requires that you first create the contract, which is defined by using an interface.
trans-unit.target: Creating a REST-style Service Bus service requires that you first create the contract, which is defined by using an interface.

trans-unit.source: The next step is to implement the interface.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to implement the interface.

trans-unit.source: This involves creating a class named ImageService that implements the user-defined IImageContract interface.
trans-unit.target: This involves creating a class named ImageService that implements the user-defined IImageContract interface.

trans-unit.source: After you implement the contract, you then configure the interface using an App.config file.
trans-unit.target: After you implement the contract, you then configure the interface using an App.config file.

trans-unit.source: The configuration file contains necessary information for the application, such as the name of the service, the name of the contract, and the type of protocol that is used to communicate with Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: The configuration file contains necessary information for the application, such as the name of the service, the name of the contract, and the type of protocol that is used to communicate with Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: The code used for these tasks is provided in the example following the procedure.
trans-unit.target: The code used for these tasks is provided in the example following the procedure.

trans-unit.source: As with the previous steps, there is very little difference between implementing a REST-style contract and a basic Service Bus contract.
trans-unit.target: As with the previous steps, there is very little difference between implementing a REST-style contract and a basic Service Bus contract.

trans-unit.source: Create a new class named ImageService directly after the definition of the IImageContract interface.
trans-unit.target: Create a new class named ImageService directly after the definition of the IImageContract interface.

trans-unit.source: The ImageService class implements the IImageContract interface.
trans-unit.target: The ImageService class implements the IImageContract interface.

trans-unit.source: Apply the ServiceBehaviorAttribute attribute to the IImageService class to indicate that the class is an implementation of a WCF contract.
trans-unit.target: Apply the ServiceBehaviorAttribute attribute to the IImageService class to indicate that the class is an implementation of a WCF contract.

trans-unit.source: Add a .jpg image to your project.
trans-unit.target: Add a .jpg image to your project.

trans-unit.source: This is a picture that the service displays in the receiving browser.
trans-unit.target: This is a picture that the service displays in the receiving browser.

trans-unit.source: Right-click your project, then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Right-click your project, then click Add.

trans-unit.source: Then click Existing Item.
trans-unit.target: Then click Existing Item.

trans-unit.source: Use the Add Existing Item dialog box to browse to an appropriate .jpg, and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Use the Add Existing Item dialog box to browse to an appropriate .jpg, and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: When adding the file, make sure that All Files is selected in the drop-down list next to the File name: field.
trans-unit.target: When adding the file, make sure that All Files is selected in the drop-down list next to the File name: field.

trans-unit.source: The rest of this tutorial assumes that the name of the image is "image.jpg".
trans-unit.target: The rest of this tutorial assumes that the name of the image is "image.jpg".

trans-unit.source: If you have a different file, you will have to rename the image, or change your code to compensate.
trans-unit.target: If you have a different file, you will have to rename the image, or change your code to compensate.

trans-unit.source: To make sure that the running service can find the image file, in Solution Explorer right-click the image file.
trans-unit.target: To make sure that the running service can find the image file, in Solution Explorer right-click the image file.

trans-unit.source: In the Properties pane, set Copy to Output Directory to Copy if newer.
trans-unit.target: In the Properties pane, set Copy to Output Directory to Copy if newer.

trans-unit.source: Add references to the System.Drawing.dll, System.Runtime.Serialization.dll, and Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll assemblies to the project, and also add the following associated using statements.
trans-unit.target: Add references to the System.Drawing.dll, System.Runtime.Serialization.dll, and Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll assemblies to the project, and also add the following associated using statements.

trans-unit.source: In the ImageService class, add the following constructor that loads the bitmap and prepares to send it to the client browser.
trans-unit.target: In the ImageService class, add the following constructor that loads the bitmap and prepares to send it to the client browser.

trans-unit.source: Directly after the previous code, add the following GetImage method in the ImageService class to return an HTTP message that contains the image.
trans-unit.target: Directly after the previous code, add the following GetImage method in the ImageService class to return an HTTP message that contains the image.

trans-unit.source: From the Build menu, click Build Solution.
trans-unit.target: From the Build menu, click Build Solution.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the ImageListener project.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the ImageListener project.

trans-unit.source: Then click Add, then New Item.
trans-unit.target: Then click Add, then New Item.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, double-click App.config, which currently contains the following XML elements.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click App.config, which currently contains the following XML elements.

trans-unit.source: Add a XML element to the App.config file. This is a WCF element that defines one or more services. Here, it is used to define the service name and endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Add a XML element to the App.config file. This is a WCF element that defines one or more services. Here, it is used to define the service name and endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Within the system.serviceModel element, add a element that has the following content. This defines the bindings used in the application. You can define multiple bindings, but for this tutorial you are defining only one.
trans-unit.target: Within the system.serviceModel element, add a element that has the following content. This defines the bindings used in the application. You can define multiple bindings, but for this tutorial you are defining only one.

trans-unit.source: After the element, add a element. Similar to the bindings, you can define multiple services in a single configuration file. However, for this tutorial, you define only one.
trans-unit.target: After the element, add a element. Similar to the bindings, you can define multiple services in a single configuration file. However, for this tutorial, you define only one.

trans-unit.source: After the element, create a element with the following content, replacing "SAS_KEY" with the Shared Access Signature (SAS) key you obtained from the Azure portal in Step 1.
trans-unit.target: After the element, create a element with the following content, replacing "SAS_KEY" with the Shared Access Signature (SAS) key you obtained from the Azure portal in Step 1.

trans-unit.source: From the Build menu, click Build Solution to build the entire solution.
trans-unit.target: From the Build menu, click Build Solution to build the entire solution.

trans-unit.source: The following code shows the contract and service implementation for a REST-based service that is running on Service Bus using the WebHttpRelayBinding binding.
trans-unit.target: The following code shows the contract and service implementation for a REST-based service that is running on Service Bus using the WebHttpRelayBinding binding.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the App.config file associated with the service.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the App.config file associated with the service.

trans-unit.source: This step describes how to run a web service using a console application on Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: This step describes how to run a web service using a console application on Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: A complete listing of the code written in this step is provided in the example following the procedure.
trans-unit.target: A complete listing of the code written in this step is provided in the example following the procedure.

trans-unit.source: In the Main() function declaration, create a variable to store the namespace of your Service Bus project.
trans-unit.target: In the Main() function declaration, create a variable to store the namespace of your Service Bus project.

trans-unit.source: Create a Uri instance for the base address of the service that is based on the namespace.
trans-unit.target: Create a Uri instance for the base address of the service that is based on the namespace.

trans-unit.source: Create the web service host, using the URI address created earlier in this section.
trans-unit.target: Create the web service host, using the URI address created earlier in this section.

trans-unit.source: Open the service.
trans-unit.target: Open the service.

trans-unit.source: Display a message indicating that the service is running, and how to stop the service.
trans-unit.target: Display a message indicating that the service is running, and how to stop the service.

trans-unit.source: When finished, close the service host.
trans-unit.target: When finished, close the service host.

trans-unit.source: The following example includes the service contract and implementation from previous steps in the tutorial and hosts the service in a console application.
trans-unit.target: The following example includes the service contract and implementation from previous steps in the tutorial and hosts the service in a console application.

trans-unit.source: Compile the following code into an executable named ImageListener.exe.
trans-unit.target: Compile the following code into an executable named ImageListener.exe.

trans-unit.source: After building the solution, do the following to run the application:
trans-unit.target: After building the solution, do the following to run the application:

trans-unit.source: From a command prompt, run the service (ImageListener\bin\Debug\ImageListener.exe).
trans-unit.target: From a command prompt, run the service (ImageListener\bin\Debug\ImageListener.exe).

trans-unit.source: Copy and paste the address from the command prompt into a browser to see the image.
trans-unit.target: Copy and paste the address from the command prompt into a browser to see the image.
